thread.title: Five dead in Melbourne air crash after plane plummets into shopping centre and explodes into massive fireball
thread.title_full: Five dead in Melbourne air crash after plane plummets into shopping centre and explodes into massive fireball

title: Five dead in Melbourne air crash after plane plummets into shopping centre and explodes into massive fireball
text:
'LIKE AN ATOMIC BOMB' Five dead in Melbourne air crash after plane plummets into shopping centre and explodes into massive fireball 
Witnesses described seeing a loud and fiery explosion as the plane crashed, killing everyone on board BY CHLOE KERR, YASMIN JEFFERY and LAURA BURNIP 21st February 2017, 7:00 am Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments FIVE people killed after their plane exploded in a “massive fireball” in Australia today included a group of golfers on a “once in a lifetime” trip round the world. 
The light aircraft crashed just after 9am local time today minutes after taking off from Essendon Airport near Melbourne, Australia, killing everyone on board including the pilot. Facebook/Jordan Fouracre The area was engulfed in flames Plane sparks explosion after crashing into shopping centre, killing five 
The pilot reported a "catastrophic engine failure" moments before the plane crashed into a storage area at the rear of the mall, police said. 
The four passengers were a group of American golfers playing their way around the world on the trip of a lifetime, news.com.au reports. 
Two of those killed have been named by family as Greg De Haven and Russell Munsch, from Texas. 
Mr De Haven, 70, was a retired FBI agent, and Mr Munsch was a founding partner of Munsch Hardt law firm. 
Mr De Haven’s sister Denelle Wicht broke the news in a Facebook post: “Dear friends and family, my handsome athletic big brother was killed today in a plane accident while on his ‘once in a lifetime’ trip to Australia.” “It was a charter flight with 2 of his friends flying to another island to play golf.” 
Carol Holst, a cousin of Mr Munsch, posted a picture of him, saying: “Russ was killed in a plane crash in Australia today. Hug your loved ones. You never know.” The pair were travelling with two other friends, who have not yet been named. 
Shocking dashcam footage shows the horrifying few seconds before the plane crashes as it quickly descends towards the shopping centre after its engine failed, disappearing behind the building. Horrifying moment plane plummets towards shopping centre near Melbourne airport Facebook/Jordan Fouracre Witnesses described seeing a loud and fiery explosion, with thick smoke wafting up from the scene of the crash Sky News The charter plane crashed just after 9am after veering during take-off Two dead and three missing after plane crashes into Australian shopping centre 
The group were understood to be travelling with their partners, who were on a separate trip while the four flew to play golf on King Island. 
Victoria police assistant commissioner Stephen Leane said: "Five on the aircraft and looks like no-one has survived the crash." 
Victoria premier Daniel Andrews described it as the state's worst air accident in three decades. 
The private charter from Essendon, north of Melbourne, to King Island, 55 minutes to the south, came down just short of a major motorway packed with the heavy traffic of early morning commuters. Reuters 90 firefighters were at the scene after the plane exploded in a massive fireball Reuters Incredibly, nobody in the shopping centre appears to have been hurt in the crash EPA Employees comfort each other at the scene of a plane crash in Essendon, Australia Sky News The aircraft is believed to have clipped a building near Melbourne's Essendon airport on Tuesday morning Facebook Russell Mensch was identified as one of the victims by his family on social media Facebook 23 Greg De Haven, 70, was also identified by his family in a Facebook post as one of the victims 
Pilot Mr Quartermain, who had more than 38 years of flying experience, reportedly made two mayday calls before the aircraft plunged to the ground. 
Pals paid tribute to the "true gentleman" with "an impeccable safety record" after the disaster, described by Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews as "the worst civil aviation incident in the state in 30 years". 
Live television footage showed burned out wreckage, flames and major damage at the shopping centre and adjacent buildings. 
A column of thick black smoke rose into the air as witnesses spoke of an explosion. 
"It appears a light plane, which is a charter flight, has impacted the DFO (Direct Factory Outlet) at Essendon Fields," police minister Lisa Neville said. 
The centre was not due to open for another hour and the authorities confirmed no one inside was hurt. Sky News The area near the Direct Factory Outlet is currently being evacuated Sky News One witness described the explosion as looking like an 'atomic bomb' Sky News The five-person plane is believed to have been headed to King Island, which is one of the islands that makes up the state of Tasmania 
"There's also debris that's been left on the freeway," she added. 
A taxi driver called ABC radio and told of the "massive fireball". 
"I saw this plane ... when it hit the building there was a massive fireball," said the man called Jason. 
"I could feel the heat through the window of the taxi, and then a wheel -- it looked like a plane wheel -- bounced on the road and hit the front of the taxi as we were driving along." EPA Police said motorists can expect roads in the vicinity of the crash to be congested for some time EPA Emergency services rushed to the scene and worked on extinguishing flames EPA Witnesses said the plane was flying 'really low and fast' before it crashed RELATED STORIES Five dead as plane crashes into shopping centre and explodes seconds after takeoff 'WAS THAT AIRLINER MEANT TO BE BENEATH ME? Harrison Ford, 74, faces losing his pilot's licence after near-miss with jet Touching tribute 'Angel boy' who helped rescue Chapecoense stars from plane crash has new home built as reward MUNICH REMEMBERED Manchester United lost eight players in the Munich air disaster on 6 Feb 1958, causing the football world to come together just as it has for tragic Brazilian side Chapecoense PLANE CRAZY Brit backpacker survives plane crash in middle of Australia... but then parties for a month with a BROKEN BACK flying squad Chapecoense take next step on road to recovery as their newly-assembled squad fly for the first time since devastating Colombia plane crash EPA Locals said they could 'feel the heat' from the crash through car windows EPA Victorian Police Minister Lisa Neville assured a full suite of emergency services were in force following the incident 
Victoria police superintendent Mick Frewen said investigations centred on a "catastrophic engine failure". 
The flight made a May-Day call before crashing, he added. 
A DFO shopworker identified as Ash told Sky News he saw "the fireball go up into the air", adding it "felt like a bomb had gone off". 
"The fire was just so hot we could not get anywhere near it," he said. "We could see the wreckage, or what was left of it. Twitter Plumes of smoke could be seen billowing from the crash site in Essendon Twitter The five-person aircraft crash has been described as a 'very very tragic accident' by Police Minister Lisa Neville Twitter Witnesses described seeing a 'big fireball' after the plane crashed into the shopping centre Twitter Emergency services are currently attending the scene, and the surrounding areas have been evacuated Twitter According to local firefighters, the blaze is still burning, so investigators have been unable to get closer to inspect the damage Twitter Police are yet to confirm the number of casualties following the crash on Tuesday morning 
Plumber Michael Howard, 29, told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation he saw a "blue flash". 
"I was ... just looking out the window ... and then all of a sudden I just saw a blue flash come down and then all of a sudden there was a massive fireball." 
"It was like something from a movie," Howard said. Horrific scenes from Essendon. Hard to fathom such an ordinary morning could turn so tragic. 
— Bill Shorten (@billshortenmp) February 20, 2017 More than 60 firefighters have worked hard to bring the fire at DFO near #Essendon under control. Crews to remain on scene for some time pic.twitter.com/R1Y8ygSxOg 
— Paul Stacchino (@MFBChief) February 20, 2017 Our hearts go out to all those affected by this morning’s tragedy at Essendon Airport. 
— Melbourne Airport (@Melair) February 20, 2017 
Melbourne fire brigade chief Paul Stacchino tweeted that "more than 60 firefighters have worked hard to bring the fire ... under control. Crews to remain on scene for some time". 
The Australian Safety Transport Bureau said it had sent investigators to the scene. 
Essendon Fields had been closed and all traffic diverted to Melbourne's two larger airports Tullamarine and Avalon. 
One side of a major freeway which runs alongside the local airport remained shut to allow wreckage to be cleared.
